refnamediv.refpurpose: find a substring that matches the regular expression string

refsynopsisdiv.title: Syntax
refsynopsisdiv.synopsis: [start] = regexp(input, pattern, [flag]) [start, final] = regexp(input, pattern, [flag]) [start, final, match] = regexp(input, pattern, [flag]) [start, final, match, foundString] = regexp(input, pattern, [flag])

listitem.para: a character string (under the rules of regular expression).
the starting index of each substring of input that matches the regular expression string pattern.
the ending index of each substring of input that matches the regular expression string pattern.
the text of each substring of input that matches pattern.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The rules of regular expression are similar to Perl language. For a quick start, see http://perldoc.perl.org/perlrequick.html. For a more in-depth tutorial on, see http://perldoc.perl.org/perlretut.html and for the reference page, see http://perldoc.perl.org/perlre.html
A difference with Perl is that matching a position but no character (for example, with /^/ or /(?=o)/) is a successful match in Perl but not in Scilab.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.programlisting:
regexp('xabyabbbz','/ab*/','o') regexp('a!','/((((((((((a))))))))))\041/') regexp('ABCC','/^abc$/i') regexp('ABC','/ab|cd/i') [a b c]=regexp('XABYABBBZ','/ab*/i')
piString="3.14" [a,b,c,piStringSplit]=regexp(piString,"/(\d+)\.(\d+)/") disp(piStringSplit(1)) disp(piStringSplit(2))
[a,b,c,d]=regexp('xabyabbbz','/ab(.*)b(.*)/') size(d)
// get host name from URL myURL="http://www.scilab.org/download/"; [a,b,c,d]=regexp(myURL,'@^(?:http://)?([^/]+)@i')
str='foobar: 2012'; // Using named subpatterns [a,b,c,d]=regexp(str,'/(?P<name>\w+): (?P<digit>\d+)/') d(1)=="foobar" d(2)=="2012"

revision.revremark: A new output argument, foundString, has been added to retrieve subpatterns matches.
